awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Recognition of Gender Stereotyping as a Determinant of Stereotype Assimilation and Contrast Effects Resulting from Subtle Bias Exposure in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Women have been historically underrepresented in STEM fields, and research evidence suggests that subtle gender bias occurs in many STEM settings, especially those where women continue to be underrepresented. Social psychological research has demonstrated the negative effects of perceived bias or becoming aware that one is the target of stereotyping and discrimination. This project will provide a novel contribution to and extension of the perceived bias research by proposing that simply witnessing instances of subtle gender bias can have differential effects on observers depending on whether they recognize the event as an instance of gender stereotyping. When witnesses observe stereotypic interactions but do not perceive them as instances of gender stereotyping, the interactions serve as a subtle stereotype cue that promotes stereotype-supporting outcomes. When witnesses to bias do recognize the stereotypic interactions as instances of gender stereotyping, the interactions serve as a blatant stereotype cue promoting stereotype-defying outcomes. The researchers will undertake a series of studies designed to experimentally test the effects of subtle vs. blatant stereotype activation (cued by witnessing bias on men and women in computer science and engineering contexts) focusing on performance, motivation, evaluation of peers, and group dynamics. The findings will inform ongoing and future intervention efforts aimed at raising awareness of and mitigating negative effects of gender bias in the STEM environment. The proposed project is a joint effort between the University of Michigan Ann Arbor and Michigan Technological University and is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances fundamental research on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

This research effort will advance the discovery and understanding of mechanisms by which the presence of subtle gender bias influences the climate for men and women in STEM by specifically exploring process differences for blatant and implicit bias cues. The work will provide insight into the influences of these cues on performance and motivation among women, as well as the behaviors of men and women in groups and on teams. One strength of this work is the use of experimental methodology (i.e. randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to study the effects of witnessing subtle bias. Using RCTs provides a rigorous test of a causal relationship between exposure to subtle bias and its purported consequences. Moreover, this research project will also expand research and theory on the effects of experienced discrimination, by examining these effects on witnesses of bias, including men, with important downstream consequences. By exploring these relationships, the research will afford better understanding of how the awareness and attribution of subtle gender bias may modify outcomes for everyone in the setting. This understanding may inform ongoing and future intervention efforts aimed at raising awareness of and mitigating negative outcomes of gender bias in the STEM environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Subtle gender bias is a common aspect of the STEM educational environment, especially in majors where women are under-represented and stereotyped as being less competent.  In a series of experiments, we measured the reaction of both men and women to videotaped scenes of subtle gender bias within a team of engineering students to identify how recognition of the presence of bias might influence important outcomes such as stereotype beliefs, enthusiasm for teamwork, and performance.  Our hypothesis is that with recognition of subtle bias comes the opportunity for stereotype-defying behaviors that break a recursive cycle in which bias breeds more bias, and lead to improved outcomes for both men and women in this environment (Figure 1).

 

We found that participants who witnessed subtle gender bias reported greater stereotype beliefs (such as assuming women are inferior in math and science) when they failed to recognize events as gender bias. When they did recognize events as bias, they reported stereotype beliefs at levels like those who did not witness bias. This pattern suggests that exposure to subtle gender bias events may have activated gender stereotypes, but when participants recognized the events as gender bias, they were able to temper their stereotype beliefs, opening the door for stereotype-defying behaviors that break the cycle of reinforcement. In addition, we found that when women recognize gender bias in an educational teamwork environment, they are less enthused about engaging in teamwork, even though their performance remains consistent with or without recognition. 

 

Interestingly, among the participants who were exposed to subtle gender bias, women were much more likely than men to recognize it, leading to an environment in which women disproportionately bear the responsibility for breaking the recursive cycle of bias that they experience. The question then becomes, “How might we help more men to recognize subtle bias?” To answer this question, we need to understand how men make sense of subtle bias that they witness and what mental models or frameworks they use in its detection and recognition. A related study revealed that white men employ five key mental model components that act as barriers to recognition of subtle gender bias: in-group favoritism (the pattern of favoring one’s own group members), victim blaming (placing the blame for negative behavior on the victim, rather than the perpetrator), the imagining of elaborate back-stories to explain negative behaviors, blaming negative behaviors on individual traits rather than systemic factors like stereotypes, and lack of recognition of the negative impacts of accumulated effects on targets of bias.  Recognition of subtle bias depended on mental model components involving the knowledge of common language (e.g. knowing and being able to recognize “mansplaining”), use of emotional intelligence, and expressions of empathy. In addition, men in this study, regardless of recognition of bias, reported discomfort, agitation, and stress toward the end of the video often without fully understanding why they experienced these emotional responses.  

 

Thus, to break the recursive cycle of bias and provide more opportunities for stereotype-defying behavior, especially among majority members, it is important to offer opportunities in higher education to increase individuals’ capacities for emotional intelligence and empathy.  In addition, offering common language to better describe bias behaviors and providing guidance on how to recognize barriers to bias recognition could lead to ally behavior among majority individuals.  Overall, such advances can break the recursive cycle, and result in an environment in which all team members feel welcomed, valued and untroubled, that they belong in the environment, and can perform to their potential.
